title: Bhagavad Gita Chapter 1 - Observing the Armies on the Battlefield of Kuruksetra

questions.prompt: In BG 1.1, what question does Dhritarastra ask Sanjaya?
choices: What did my sons and the sons of Pandu do on the battlefield of Kuruksetra?
Who will win the battle between the Kauravas and Pandavas?
Why did the Pandavas come to Kuruksetra?
What weapons were used by both sides?
questions.feedback: Correct. Dhritarastra asks what his sons and the sons of Pandu did on the battlefield of Kuruksetra, revealing his anxiety and attachment.

questions.prompt: Why does Dhritarastra specifically mention Kuruksetra in BG 1.1?
choices: Because Kuruksetra was a holy place that could influence the outcome
Because Kuruksetra belonged to the Kauravas
Because Kuruksetra was difficult to reach
Because Kuruksetra had never seen war before
questions.feedback: Correct. The purport explains that Kuruksetra was a sacred place, and Dhritarastra feared its spiritual influence might favor the Pandavas.

questions.prompt: In BG 1.2, how does Sanjaya begin his response to Dhritarastra?
choices: By describing Duryodhana approaching his teacher Dronacarya
By listing the warriors on both sides
By describing the blowing of conchshells
questions.feedback: Correct. Sanjaya immediately focuses on Duryodhana approaching Dronacarya, setting the tone for the chapter.

questions.prompt: What does Duryodhana point out to Dronacarya in BG 1.3?
choices: The military strength of the Pandavas arranged by Dhrstadyumna
The weakness of the Kaurava army
questions.feedback: Correct. Duryodhana draws attention to the Pandava army, subtly criticizing Drona’s role in training their commander.

questions.prompt: According to the purport of BG 1.3, what mentality does Duryodhana display?
questions.feedback: Correct. The purport highlights Duryodhana’s fear and his attempt to subtly blame Drona for strengthening the enemy.

questions.prompt: In BG 1.4-1.6, what is Duryodhana mainly doing?
choices: Listing prominent warriors on both sides
questions.feedback: Correct. Duryodhana enumerates great fighters, trying to reassure himself and his allies.

questions.prompt: Why does Duryodhana emphasize warriors like Bhisma and Karna?
choices: To boost morale and suppress inner fear
questions.feedback: Correct. The purport explains that Duryodhana speaks to counteract his own insecurity.

questions.prompt: In BG 1.7, why does Duryodhana instruct Drona to be mindful?
choices: Because the Kaurava army depends on coordinated leadership
Because Drona doubts the Kaurava cause
questions.feedback: Correct. Duryodhana urges alertness, reflecting his concern about maintaining unity and strength.

questions.prompt: In BG 1.8, what role does Bhisma play in Duryodhana’s speech?
choices: He is presented as the chief protector of the Kaurava army
He is criticized for his neutrality
He is shown as uncertain about fighting
He is compared unfavorably to Arjuna
questions.feedback: Correct. Duryodhana highlights Bhisma as the greatest strength and protector of their army.

questions.prompt: According to the purport of BG 1.8, what subtle weakness exists despite Bhisma’s presence?
questions.feedback: Correct. The purport notes Bhisma’s inner sympathy for the Pandavas, which limits Duryodhana’s confidence.

questions.prompt: Why does Sanjaya describe the blowing of conchshells in BG 1.12-1.13?
choices: To signal the formal beginning of battle
questions.feedback: Correct. The conchshells mark the commencement of battle and set the emotional atmosphere.

questions.prompt: What distinguishes the Pandavas’ conchshells in BG 1.14?
choices: They are blown by Krsna and Arjuna together
They are louder than the Kauravas’
questions.feedback: Correct. The verse highlights Krsna and Arjuna blowing their conchshells, indicating divine support.

questions.prompt: According to the purport of BG 1.14, what is the deeper significance of Krsna’s presence?
choices: Victory is assured when Krsna is on one side
questions.feedback: Correct. The purport emphasizes that divine support guarantees ultimate success.

questions.prompt: Why does Arjuna ask Krsna to place the chariot between the armies in BG 1.21-1.22?
choices: To see who has assembled to fight
questions.feedback: Correct. Arjuna wants to observe those who desire to fight in the battle.

questions.prompt: What realization begins to form in Arjuna upon seeing his relatives?
questions.feedback: Correct. The sight of relatives triggers Arjuna’s internal crisis.

questions.prompt: In BG 1.27, what emotional transformation does Arjuna experience?
questions.feedback: Correct. Arjuna becomes overwhelmed by compassion and sorrow.

questions.prompt: Why does Arjuna argue that killing his relatives would be sinful?
questions.feedback: Correct. Arjuna fears the collapse of family and social order.

questions.prompt: According to the purport, what flaw exists in Arjuna’s reasoning?
choices: It is based on bodily attachment rather than spiritual duty
questions.feedback: Correct. The purport explains that Arjuna’s arguments arise from material identification.

questions.prompt: How does BG Chapter 1 primarily function in the structure of the Gita?
choices: It sets up Arjuna’s crisis that necessitates spiritual instruction
questions.feedback: Correct. The chapter establishes the psychological and moral dilemma.

questions.prompt: Why does Krsna remain silent throughout Chapter 1?
choices: To allow Arjuna’s confusion to fully manifest
questions.feedback: Correct. The silence allows the crisis to mature before instruction begins.
